text.tspan: (1) if helpful, then RL is rewarded
(2) if RL predict latent state, also reward
Rule tail = linear composition of values
= tokens (can be interpreted as logic propositions)
= original LLM (Transformer) architecture. Yellow strip = middle hidden
layer, where the most abstract representation is supposed to emerge.
= middle layer of LLM = "state" of RL, made of a horizontal row of tokens.
= input sentence. LLM is like Helen Keller, reading a single word each
time. At time step t+1, Transformer generates a vertical column of tokens,
that includes the prediction of the next word.
1) Per each iteration, the Transformer inputs a new token
and outputs a new token. RL wants to put that token back
into Working Memory, and this generates more tokens. So
each RL cycle adds one new token to Working Memory.
2) In current LLMs, every token has its "pivot", ie, the word
that originally generated it. That is the observed world
change "delta." Each token is the local conclutions
deduced from the delta change. So, the way our RL
operates, leads to more than one conclusion at each time t.
In order to conform to LLM's format, it seems that we need
to add these tokens together (superposition) to make a
single token. But this may cause information overflow in the
Perhaps a better solution is: Set the newest token as "pivot",
place the other new tokens to its left, as supplementary
information to aid prediction. But this requires modifying
the LLM code. Hopefully it will require only fine-tuning and
